Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Automatic Generation of As-Built BIM Models Using a Single Video Camera
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to transform commercial construction through the democratization of scanning and automation of Building Information Modeling (BIM). Constant design and change management is a unique challenge that is costing the US construction industry billions of dollars annually. BIM allows significant reduction of these costs by facilitating an early analysis and decision-making process. The existing manual as-built BIM modeling technologies are only viable for large-scale commercial construction projects because the process is too laborious and expensive; in small projects, the projected savings hardly justify adopting the process. The proposed Scan-to-BIM technology has the potential to eliminate these barriers. Its ease-of-use, reduced file size, and automated object detection enable more scans and create more robust data models, unlocking the latent potential of the BIM process. Enormous value could be generated due to streamlining and data management capabilities that are offered by the technology in the form of accelerated project schedules, reduced number of requests for information and change orders, and timely identified design clashes. This paves the way to increasing the competitiveness of the US construction industry, by enabling new services that support automatic BIM modeling and effective infrastructure management.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will investigate the technical and commercial feasibility of an automatic solution for the Scan-to-BIM problem in the construction industry. Scan-to-BIM refers to 3D scanning of a physical structure (in the form of a dense point cloud) and converting the raw spatial data into an object-oriented, semantically-rich model. Although there are a few technologies that aim to facilitate this process, the 3D modeling component remains primarily a manual and time-consuming task. When using the proposed technology, if proved to be feasible, a non-technical worker videotapes the target structure. The video is automatically sent to a server for processing. A unique videogrammetric framework reconstructs the 3D geometry of the structure. This generates a dense point cloud, an edge cloud, and a line cloud (which are still raw but more meaningful spatial data). It then extracts object hypotheses from key frames and spatial data in the form of observations. Afterwards, it optimizes a joint probability distribution function and infers a 3D layout. The outcome is an object-oriented 3D representation of the structure with embedded geometrical attributes and property sets. This advances the state-of-the-art in robust intelligence, particularly the interpretation of complex, unstructured data.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Building Information Modeling (BIM) is a process that generates an object-oriented, digital representation of a physical structure and its functional characteristics to be used through the lifecycle of a project. Despite significant progress in effective and reliable reconstruction of 3D BIM of existing built environments, there is no practical approach that allows generating 3D models that accurately represent the geometry, topology, and semantics of the buildings. A valid and complete 3D digital model must include three components: a) geometry which defines boundary, shape, and dimensions of individual objects; b) topology which defines the relationships among building components; and c) semantics which defines additional characteristics through dedicated attributes (e.g., material type, functionality, cost information, etc.). Existing as-built BIM modeling solutions receive a laser-scanned 3D point cloud as the input data and identify a set of points that follow geometrical properties of primitive shapes (state-of-the-art products can only extract planar or cylindrical surfaces); these points are then segmented from the point cloud and replaced by an object that represents the extracted geometry. Such solutions result in detailed geometrical information for objects with primitive geometry but fall short in extracting geometry of complex objects. Significant human intervention is therefore needed to segment the points belonging to complex objects.

The ultimate objective of this SBIR project is to investigate the technical and commercial feasibility of automating the entire process of so-called “Scan-to-BIM” by using inexpensive, off-the-shelf cameras; this includes geometry, topology, and semantics. During the Phase I/IB, the goal was to evaluate the feasibility of automatically identifying and segmenting building components with primitive or complex geometry from a 3D point-edge-line cloud and its corresponding video frames. This aims at the first component of the three essential components for a complete BIM (i.e., geometry).

During the Phase I, Pointivo presented a novel videogrammetric solution for the Scan-to-BIM problem. When using the proposed solution, a video stream is recorded of a structure using a camera. This camera could be of any type or form. The 3D scanning component of the technology processes each and every frame of the video to recover the camera trajectory and the 3D geometry of the structure. Given these data, several 2D/3D observations are formulated. Subsequently, the geometry of scene components/objects are detected and described in 3D. The main novelty of this technology lies in a hybrid approach that combines low-level segmentation with high-level space modeling; this transforms the inference of the BIM model into a narrow interpretation space. Existing recognition methods are typically prone to false alarms because they only depend on 2D image data OR structured 3D point clouds. However, the proposed technology uses a novel coherent joint probability function that combines 2D and 3D data in a single formulation which enables reasoning at the geometrical level; this creates the missing link between visual object recognition and remote sensing. The feasibility of this innovation was established during the Phase I project through:

  • Re-designing the entire technical framework such that it reflects the modified commercialization goals and a modular technology development approach, which allows for multiple software releases and revenue streams
  • Proving the concept for activities/steps that have the highest technical risk (i.e., formulate observations; detect and describe scene objects)
  • Performing feasibility studies to answer the question of “should we proceed with the proposed project idea?” both from a technical perspective ...
